Every Product Fails Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(3) API are Products

  • Products should focus on user needs and consumability
  • APIs should go beyond the happy path and expose useful error messages
  • API designers should focus on business logic concerns


Every Product Fails Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(4) API Guidelines

  • More API teams mean more ways to solve the same problem
    • Solving API problems is not what teams should focus on
    • Solving API problems in a consistent way helps the API landscape
  • Anatomy of a Good Guideline
    • Why does the guideline exist?
    • What can be done to address the described issue
    • How to implement the solution
    • Testing that the guideline has been followed


Every Product Fails Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

HTTP Status Codes Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(12) Status Codes are about Application Semantics

  • Pick the most appropriate status code
  • Clients must treat unknown status codes as generic X00 responses
  • OpenAPI's response object [https://spec.openapis.org/oas/latest.html#responses-object] supports listing response status codes
    • Not all possible status codes have to be listed
    • There should be (at least) one successful status code
    • Known errors should should be listed in the response object


HTTP Problem Details

HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(14) HTTP Problem Details

  • HTTP status codes [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-status-code/] are useful but minimalistic
    • Their well-defined semantics allow intermediaries to act on them
    • Servers may want to convey additional information with them
  • APIs may include problem details as part of their representation designs
    • Using a standard reduces the design work on the server side
    • Using a standard allows developers to more easily understand the design
    • Using a standard allows problem details analysis across APIs
  • RFC 7807 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html]/9457 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html] defines a JSON-centric model for problem details
    • application/problem+json is a JSON-based representation of the problem detail model
    • application/problem+xml is an XML-based representation of the problem detail model


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(15) HTTP Problem Details: JSON 

{
  "type": "https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit",
  "title": "You do not have enough credit.",
  "detail": "Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.",
  "instance": "/account/12345/msgs/abc",
  "balance": 30,
  "accounts": [
    "/account/12345",
    "/account/67890"
  ]
}
  • http-problem-details.json


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(16) HTTP Problem Details: XML 

<problem xmlns="urn:ietf:rfc:7807">
  <type>https://example.com/probs/out-of-credit</type>
  <title>You do not have enough credit.</title>
  <detail>Your current balance is 30, but that costs 50.</detail>
  <instance>https://example.net/account/12345/msgs/abc</instance>
  <balance>30</balance>
  <accounts>
    <i>https://example.net/account/12345</i>
    <i>https://example.net/account/67890</i>
  </accounts>
</problem>
  • http-problem-details.xml


HTTP Problem Details Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(17) TMI Error

  • Avoid any implementation information
  • This is about helping clients
  • This is not about providing debugging information

RFC 9457: The New RFC 7807 Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(21) Differences between RFC 7807 and RFC 9457

  • There are no breaking changes
  • Three issues seen from usage in the wild
    • Registry of common problem type URIs (Section 4.2 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#registry])
    • Clarification of how to treat multiple problems (Section 3 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#problem-json])
    • Guidance for using type URIs that cannot be dereferenced (Section 3.1.1 [https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9457.html#type])

Conclusions Erik Wilde: Practical API Management with OpenAPI: Error Messages for HTTP APIs

(27) Proper Use. Guiding People. Extending When Necessary.

  • Use HTTP status codes to report service status
  • Create guidelines so that your APIs behave coherently
  • Extend HTTP with problem reports for more detailed responses
